Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the joint conferences "Young Mathematicians in C*-Algebras" and "Young Women in C*-Algebras" that will be held August 5-10, 2019 at the University of Copenhagen. This joint conference focuses on recent developments in operator algebras (both von Neumann and C*-algebras), noncommutative geometry, and related areas of mathematical analysis, with a particular emphasis on the interplay between operator algebras and the fields of geometric group theory, logic, and dynamical systems.

Young Mathematicians in C*-Algebras and Young Women in C*-Algebras are organized for and by master/Ph.D.-students and postdocs in operator algebras and related areas, with the goal of fostering scientific and social interaction between young researchers. The conference will feature three mini-courses by established researchers (Cornelia Drutu, Ilijas Farah, and Ian Putnam) alongside many contributed talks by participants, as well as mentoring activities designed to increase retention of underrepresented groups in operator algebras. This award gives US-based early career researchers and members of underrepresented groups an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups via advertising in a variety of venues. More information will be made available at: https://www.math.ku.dk/english/research/conferences/2019/ymcstara2019/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Young Mathematicians in C*-algebras (YMC*A) and Young Women in C*-algebras (YWC*A) conferences were held jointly at the University of Copenhagen, Denmark from August 5-10, 2019.  This grant provided funding for US-based junior researchers to attend, and thereby interact scientifically and socially with their European counterparts.  In particular, YWC*A activities promoted networking and visibility of female operator algebraists, and were meant to prevent or alleviate feelings of isolation among women in operator algebras. As YMC*A/YWC*A is run by and for graduate students and postdocs, it provides a nonthreatening environment for young researchers to talk about their work and ask questions.  This project built on the funding provided by the NSF in 2018 for US-based researchers to attend YMC*A/YWC*A 2018.  

45 researchers applied for travel support to attend YMC*A/YWC*A 2019. The NSF funded 24 US-based participants: 9 women and 15 men. NSF funding is crucial to the presence of US researchers at YMC*A/YWC*A: in 2017, when no NSF funding was available, only 5 US-based researchers attended YMC*A/YWC*A.

The exit survey for the summer 2019 conference (which 17 of the 24 funded participants responded to) provided significant evidence that YMC*A/YWC*A achieves the goals mentioned in the first paragraph.  Participants consistently said that having a conference dedicated to young researchers made it easier for them to interact with other mathematicians and ask questions or discuss ideas. One remarked, "here, it feels like every participant is completely happy to answer any questions and equally interested themselves in getting new ideas for research. I've never had a single bad experience in approaching someone at YMC*A to talk about math, and it makes the environment very conducive to facilitating research ideas and collaboration."

Attending YMC*A/YWC*A has enhanced the participants? professional opportunities.  In 2019, 7 of the NSF-funded participants were invited to give a talk at YMC*A/YWC*A. One remarked, "I was asked a question at the end of my talk which has sparked a new project that I'm just beginning to explore now." Approximately half the NSF-funded participants reported that conversations at YMC*A/YWC*A inspired new ideas for research. The benefits from attending YMC*A/YWC*A are long-lasting: for one participant, the presentations they gave at YMC*A/YWC*A 2018 "afforded me further invitations to speak at conferences in the United States."

 All 17 survey respondents attended the YWC*A panel on "Early Career Advice and Issues of Equity," and 8 attended the women's-only YWC*A mentor lunch. These events were particularly useful in promoting female operator algebraists. One participant remarked, "It's often difficult to be a woman in a field so dominated by men, and the level of support shown at this conference and the discussions about how to make things better for women in the future is outstanding. I often have doubts about my ability to succeed in this field, but after the conference, I am energized and excited about what the future will bring." Another participant thanked "Dr. Nadia Larsen's life-in-math talk for solidify[ing] my philosophy of working hard on math while looking at the big picture of this world we all share." Many found the YWC*A panel discussion and the women's mentoring lunch valuable. One participant commented on the panel, "To hear the speakers' unvarnished, unprepared opinions was very authentic and gave me insight on what the life of a mathematician is actually like."

 

The three minicourses and keynote address provided inspiration to many of the NSF-funded participants. Cornelia Drutu spoke on "C*-algebras and Geometric Group Theory," Ilijas Farah spoke on "Massive C*-algebras and their applications," Ian Putnam spoke on "C*-algebras and Dynamics," and Nadia Larsen gave a keynote address on "Equilibrium states on Nica-Toeplitz algebras" in addition to her life-in-math talk. There were several comments evidencing the usefulness of the minicourses, such as a participant engaging in an "extensive discussion with Cornelia Drutu after one of her mini-course lectures about topics that I was mostly unaware of till now, but seem very interesting and relevant to me," and another participant commenting that "the minicourse [Ilijas Farah] taught resolved questions that I had not thought to ask yet."

 

In general, YMC*A/YWC*A has a lasting effect on participants. One participant remarked that "Before attending YMC*A last year I was growing tired of the math culture at my university. I am a non-traditional student and I do not always feel like I belong. The people at YMC*A are inclusive and friendly. [...] It gave me the ambition to complete my exams and ideas on how to begin my thesis research." Another participant discussed how they met a mentor for their dissertation research in 2017, an experience which "was pivotal to me as my advisors' area of expertise was not very proximal to my research topic, so this mentor's exchanging of e-mails with me over the last two years helped immensely."
